specialization_name: Software Engineering in Test (SET) / QA Automation

quizzes.title: QA Automation Fundamentals - Level 1
quizzes.description: Basic foundations of Software Quality Assurance, testing concepts, and automation principles

questions.question_text: What is the primary purpose of Software Quality Assurance (QA)?
questions.explanation: QA's main purpose is to identify defects and ensure software meets requirements, preventing bugs from reaching end users.

options.option_text: To write the source code for new features and applications
To design the user interface and user experience of an application
To identify defects (bugs) and ensure the software meets requirements
To deploy the application to production servers for users to access
To manage the project schedule and budget

questions.question_text: What is a 'bug' or 'defect' in software?
questions.explanation: A bug is an error, flaw, or fault in a computer program that causes incorrect results or unexpected behavior.

options.option_text: An error, flaw, or fault in a computer program that causes it to produce an incorrect result
A new feature request that has not been implemented yet
A piece of hardware that is not working correctly
A log file that is generated by the application
A task for the developer to complete

questions.explanation: Black-box testing focuses on testing functionality without knowing the internal code structure.

options.option_text: Testing the internal code structure and logic of the software
Testing the software without any knowledge of its internal code or structure
A security test to see if the software can be 'hacked'
A performance test to see if the software can handle a heavy load
Testing the software after all the code has been 'locked' (boxed)

questions.explanation: White-box testing examines internal code structure, logic, and paths to ensure code quality.

options.option_text: Testing the software without any knowledge of its internal code
Testing the software's functionality from a user's perspective
Testing the internal code structure, logic, and paths of the software
A test to ensure the user interface is visually 'white' or clean
Testing the software in a secure, isolated 'white box'

questions.explanation: A test case is a detailed set of conditions, inputs, steps, and expected results used to verify a specific feature works correctly.

options.option_text: A document that describes the overall strategy for testing an application
A set of inputs, execution steps, and expected results to verify a specific feature
A 'case' or 'container' for storing all test data
A single line of code in an automation script
A report that describes a bug found in the software

questions.explanation: Manual testing involves a human tester manually interacting with the application to find bugs and verify functionality.

options.option_text: The process of using a software script to automatically test an application
The process of a human tester interacting with an application to find bugs
The process of writing a 'user manual' for the software
The process of manually building and compiling the code
The process of manually configuring the test server

questions.explanation: Automation testing uses scripts and software tools to run tests automatically, increasing speed and reliability.

options.option_text: The process of using a human tester to find bugs
The process of writing a 'user manual' for the software
The process of using software (scripts) to run tests and verify results
The process of manually writing a test plan
The process of designing the user interface

questions.explanation: A bug report is a formal document that describes a defect with all details needed to reproduce and fix it.

options.option_text: A document that lists all the new features to be built
A formal document that describes a defect, including steps to reproduce it
A test case that failed during execution
A list of all the automated tests
A log file generated by the server

questions.explanation: Functional testing verifies that the software functions correctly and meets specified requirements.

options.option_text: Testing the software's performance, like its speed
Testing the software's security against attacks
Testing the software to ensure it 'functions' and meets the specified requirements
Testing the internal code logic
Testing the usability and 'feel' of the application

questions.explanation: Non-functional testing covers aspects beyond features, such as performance, security, usability, and reliability.

options.option_text: Testing the software's core features, like a login button
Testing aspects other than features, such as performance, security, or usability
Testing a feature that is 'non-functional' or broken
A type of test that does not require a human
A test that has not been written yet

questions.explanation: Regression testing ensures that new code changes haven't broken existing functionality.

options.option_text: Testing a new feature for the first time
Testing to ensure that new code changes have not broken existing features
A test to see if the software 'regresses' or gets worse over time
A type of negative test case
Testing the software's performance

questions.explanation: SDLC stands for Software Development Life Cycle, the process of planning, creating, testing, and deploying software.

options.option_text: Software Development Life Cycle
Software Design and Logic Cycle
Secure Development Logic Check
System Deployment Life Cycle
Software Defect Life Cycle

questions.explanation: A positive test case verifies the application works as expected with valid, correct input data.

options.option_text: A test that is expected to fail
A test that verifies the application works as expected with valid data
A test that checks the application's response to invalid data
A test that a tester is 'positive' will pass
A test for a new feature

questions.explanation: A negative test case verifies that the application handles invalid data and errors correctly.

options.option_text: A test that is expected to pass
A test that verifies the application handles invalid data or errors correctly
A test that a tester is 'negative' about
A test that has failed and produced a bug
A test of an old, deprecated feature

questions.question_text: What is the 'Severity' of a bug?
questions.explanation: Severity defines the impact of a bug on the application's functionality and user experience.

options.option_text: It defines how soon the bug needs to be fixed
It defines the impact of the bug on the application's functionality
It defines how difficult the bug will be to fix
It defines the developer who is assigned to fix the bug
It defines the test case that found the bug

questions.question_text: What is the 'Priority' of a bug?
questions.explanation: Priority defines the order or urgency in which a bug should be fixed based on business needs.

options.option_text: It defines the impact of the bug on the application's functionality
It defines the order or 'urgency' in which the bug should be fixed
It defines how difficult the bug is to fix
It defines the component where the bug is located
It defines the version of the software that has the bug

questions.explanation: A test environment is the specific hardware, software, and network configuration used for testing.

options.option_text: The specific hardware, software, and network setup used for testing
The 'environment' or 'mood' of the QA team
The document that outlines the test plan
The server that runs the live production application
The software used to write automation scripts

questions.explanation: Exploratory testing is a simultaneous test design and execution approach without predefined scripts, allowing creative bug discovery.

options.option_text: A type of testing where test cases are designed and executed simultaneously without a predefined script
A type of testing that 'explores' the internal code
An automated test that 'explores' all possible user paths
A test that is 'exploring' a new, unreleased feature
A performance test that 'explores' the limits of the system

questions.explanation: Acceptance testing is performed by end-users or clients to verify the product meets their requirements before accepting it.

options.option_text: Testing performed by the developer to 'accept' the feature
Testing performed by the end-user or client to 'accept' the product
Testing to see if the application 'accepts' user input
The very first test that is run in a project
A test of the 'Terms and Conditions' acceptance box

questions.explanation: STLC stands for Software Test Life Cycle, the sequence of activities conducted during testing.

options.option_text: Software Test Life Cycle
System Test Logic Cycle
Secure Test Life Cycle
Software Technology Life Cycle
System Technology Logic Cycle
